dict.string: Use this section to define settings for S.U.P.E.R.M.A.N (super)
The human-readable description of this payload. This description appears on the Detail screen.
The human-readable name for the profile payload. The name appears on the Detail screen and doesn't need to be unique.

The reverse-DNS-style identifier for the payload. This identifier is usually the same as the `TopLevel` value, with an additional appended component. This string must be unique within the profile.
During a profile replacement, the system updates payloads with the same `PayloadIdentifier` and `PayloadUUID` in the old and new profiles.
The payload type, which each payload domain's reference page specifies.

The globally unique identifier for the payload. The actual content is unimportant, but must be globally unique. In macOS, use `uuidgen` to generate UUIDs.
During a profile replacement, the system updates payloads with the same `PayloadIdentifier` and `PayloadUUID` in the old and new profiles.
The version of this specific payload.
The human-readable string containing the name of the organization that provides the profile. This value doesn't need to match the organization payload value in the enclosing dictionary.
Prompt the end user to save their password which can then be used to authenticate the local softwareupdate command
Auth Ask User To Save Password
If any managed automatic authentication method fails validation, then failover to local end user authentication
Use this when using super with Jamf Pro API account
Allows you to override the default Jamf Pro management URL for a custom Jamf Pro API URL
The MDM workflow can be unreliable due to its complexity, and super will automatically try again upon failure, however this settings allows super to try other options
The maximum number of automatic deferrals allowed if the system is in user-enabled Focus/Do Not Disturb or when a process has requested that the display not go to sleep
The maximum number of user selected deferrals allowed before the computer automatically restarts for updates without asking the user for approval
The maximum number of user selected deferrals allowed before showing a soft deadline dialog

This is the last date and time when automatic deferrals are allowed if the system is in user-enabled Focus/Do Not Disturb or when a process has requested that the display not go to sleep (for example, during an active meeting)
If this date has passed, the computer restarts and udpates without asking the user for approval
If this date and time have passed, an interactive update restart dialog appears indicating that no more user deferrals are allowed

The maximum number of days that automatic deferrals are allowed if the system is in user-enabled Focus/Do Not Disturb or when a process has requested that the display not go to sleep (for example, during an active meeting).
The maximum number of days allowed before the computer automatically restarts for updates without asking the user for approval
The maximum number of days allowed before the soft deadline dialog. The soft deadline is an interactive update restart dialog indicating that no more deferrals are allowed
Sets an automatic timeout for the restart or defer dialog in seconds
Timeouts less than 60 seconds or more than 86400 seconds (1 day) are rounded accordingly
Make the super workflow run one or more Jamf Pro Policy Triggers that are comma separated with no spaces
Specifies a local path or web URL to a file with the content to be shown in dialogs only when showing the Apple silicon user authentication dialog
Specifies a local path or web URL to a file with the content to be shown in dialogs only when performing macOS updates
Specifies a local path or web URL to a file with the content to be shown in dialogs only when performing macOS upgrades
Instead of having super automatically select the beginning date and time of the super workflow (aka. day zero), this option sets a specific date and time as day zero
The number of minutes to defer the update restart dialog automatically if a process has prevented display sleep (for example, during an active meeting) or the user has Focus or Do Not Disturb enabled
Sets the default timeout for any dialog that doesn't have a specific timeout setting
Timeout for computers with not enough free space
Timeout for computers where power is required
Sets an automatic timeout for interactive update restart dialogs in seconds
The countdown of the timeout is displayed in the update restart dialog
On Mac computers with Apple Silicon, the number of seconds to wait for the user to successfully authenticate when presented with the user authenticated dialog
This dialog does not show a visual countdown of the timeout. Default time is 3600 seconds (1 hour)
Sets an automatic timeout for the user choice (restart/install or defer) dialog in seconds
Timeouts less than 60 seconds or more than 86400 seconds (1 day) are rounded accordingly
Sets an automatic timeout for the scheduled install user choice dialog in seconds
Timeouts less than 60 seconds or more than 86400 seconds (1 day) are rounded accordingly
User Scheduled Install User Choice Dialog Timeout
Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the default accessory
Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the accessory to display when the InstallJamfPolicyTriggers payload option is also enabled and the workflow target is only Jamf Pro Policy Triggers
Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the accessory to display when performing macOS upgrades
Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the accessory to display when performing macOS updates

Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the accessory to display when the InstallNonSystemUpdatesWithoutRestarting payload option is also enabled and the workflow target is only non-system updates

Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the accessory to display when the WorkflowRestartWithoutUpdates payload option is also enabled and the workflow target is only a forced restart without any updates
Interactive dialogs (but not notifications) generated by IBM Notifier can be easily customized via several display accessory options
The display accessory content appears below any deferral or deadline text but above any interactive item like the deferral pop-up menu or user authentication field
Plain text to display or http(s) URL link to follow for the Help Button
This option hides the animated progress bar (as opposed showing it) for notifications and alerts
Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the picture to display in notifications or dialogs when in dark mode. Failover to DisplayIconFile payload if configured
Failover to DisplayIconFile payload if configured
Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the picture to display in notifications or dialogs when in light mode. Failover to DisplayIconFile payload if configured
Failover to DisplayIconFile payload if configured
Local path or http(s) URL to a file that is the picture to display in notifications or dialogs
This remains as a default icon option and as a fail-over if the user's appearance mode cannot be resolved when Light or Dark icon files are configured
Number of pixels for the DisplayIcon in IBM Notifier dialogs
The value must be in between 96 and 150
If a restart is required for system updates or forced via RestartWithoutUpdates, this list of Jamf Policy Triggers runs before any available updates install and the computer restarts
Allows for installation of Jamf Pro Policies even if there are no available macOS updates/upgrades
Install Jamf Policies Without A Restart
Leverages the public MacAdmin's SOFA macOS machine readable JSON feed to discover release dates for use in workflows with deadline day options
Adds a Schedule button to the standard deferral dialog

When clicked, this button opens a scheduled installation dialog that allows the user to select a date and time for installation.If any day or date deadlines are also specified, then the user is not allowed to select an installation date later than the soonest deadline
Mode to validate parameters, credentials, notifications, dialogs, deferrals, and deadline logic
Kicks off the super workflow immediately, prompting user that an update has begun
Allows you to define multiple weekday time frames that specify when the super workflow is allowed to be active (aka maintenance windows)

Each schedule workflow active time frame must be specified using the following format DAY:hh:mm-hh:mm where weekdays are defined as MON|TUE|WED|THU|FRI|SAT|SUN and times are in 24-hour format. Multiple ranges are separated by a comma with no spaces
The amount of time in seconds to leave test notifications and dialogs open before moving on in the workflow
Instead of having the days deadline counter, automatically select the day zero date
Allows for a custom self-hosted MacAdmin's SOFA macOS machine readable JSON feed
Allows you to specify a date and time that a scheduled installation takes place
Allows you to specify the number of days after the zero date that a scheduled installation takes place
Allows you to specify a list of minutes separated by commas (no spaces) that define how often a scheduled installation reminder dialog appears prior to a scheduled installation
The number of minutes to defer until the next update workflow attempt if a user choses not restart
The number of minutes to defer if super detects an error in the workflow (for example, network or MDM connectivity issues)
Display a deferral time pop-up menu in the non-deadline restart dialog that allows the user to override the Deferral Timer Default timer
The number of minutes to defer if no software updates are available or allowed. Enabling this option results in super acting as a permanent agent that checks for software updates on a regular basis
Hide the background while displaying super dialogs and notifications
Display super notifications in the center of the screen
Do not play the system alert sound when opening super dialogs and notifications
Disable the users ability to move super dialogs and notifications
A plain text string or URL to open when the user clicks the warning button (exclamation mark icon) in all interactive dialogs (but not notifications)

With this option enabled super leverages built-in commands and the mist command to find compatible macOS major upgrade versions. If a newer macOS major upgrade is available then the super workflow attempts to download and install the upgrade. The default super workflow always selects the newest compatible macOS major upgrade version
Force a restart even if Apple software updates do not need it

Limit the installation of macOS major upgrade versions to the major (whole number) version specified in this option. This option requires that you have also specified the InstallMacOSMajorUpgrades option
If there are no pending restart-required macOS updates or upgrades, make the super workflow install non-system Apple software updates as soon as they become available
Install Non System Updates Without Restarting
Allow the super workflow to install macOS Rapid Security Response (RSR) updates
Disable the automatic relaunch of the super workflow when no macOS updates or upgrades are available or allowed
Disable the super workflow from checking for, downloading, or installing any Apple software updates or upgrades, even if they are available
Download and prepare macOS updates or upgrades but do not start any installation workflow
Mode to generate additional log output
